Strategy / Capability: Backup Power Conversion to Dual-fuel (Building Level)
Action: Convert Existing Backup Power to Dual-fuel (Building Level)
Description: Generators that can run on two or more fuel types (e.g., diesel, natural gas) have greater flexibility than single-fuel generators in providing backup power if the fuel supply is disrupted. The goal of this strategy is to ensure that generators covering critical building loads have the capability to use multiple fuel types. Note that Jet Propellant 8 (JP-8) is not considered a dual fuel for diesel because using JP-8 requires modifying fuel injectors and because the extended use of JP-8 requires modifying maintenance schedules.

Action: Adjust Generator Size to Avoid Wet Stacking
Description: A generator is considered right-sized if it operates at between 30 and 70% rated capacity. Diesel generators that run below 30% load do not reach the required engine temperature to fully combust fuel, resulting in wet stacking (i.e., unburned fuel passes into the exhaust system). Wet stacking increases maintenance and can cause permanent engine damage. Adjusting generator size to avoid wet stacking helps ensure that generators have at least a 30% load at all times, which can be accomplished by replacing oversized generators with lower capacity generators, increasing the connected load, or using load banks. Generators that operate at over 70% rated capacity are considered undersized and are addressed in Strategy 7, Backup Power for Critical Loads.

Action: Conduct Generator Full-Load Testing (Building Level)
Description: Regularly testing generators at their full-load capacity identifies operational issues that may arise during an emergency, removes buildup from wet stacking, and extends the generator’s usable life. This strategy helps ensure that backup power generators are tested at their full capacity. Load banks may be required for full-load testing when the full-load capacity exceeds the connected load. This strategy applies to building-level generators.

Action: Conduct Generator Hard-Drop Testing (Building Level)
Description: During an outage or emergency, the backup power for a building should be reliable and function properly. Testing backup power by cutting utility power to a building can determine whether the power transfer systems work correctly and whether all critical loads are properly connected to the backup power. This strategy applies to building-level generators.

Strategy / Capability: Backup Power Systems in Secure Structure
Action: Locate Backup Power Systems in Secure Structure
Description: Backup power systems may be subject to damage from physical threats, especially weather-related events, but must still be fully functional when required. Locating backup power systems within a secure structure helps protect them from physical threats. The definition of secure structure depends on local conditions, threats, and the system. This strategy relates to Strategy 24, Hardened Electrical Distribution Components.

Action: Install Generator Cold Weather Block Heater
Description: Generators may have fast-starting requirements but may not operate at full capacity in a cold climate. Block heaters help keep generators warm so they can start quickly in an outage.

Strategy / Capability: Backup Power for Critical Loads (Building Level)
Action: Install Backup Power for Critical Loads (Building Level)
Description: Uninterruptable critical infrastructure should have a reliable source of power even in unpredictable events. Backup systems ensure that supply failure will not compromise an uninterruptable critical asset/function. Generators that are undersized to serve critical loads should be addressed here rather than in Strategy 2, Minimum Generator Loading, because an undersized generator could be undersized because not all critical loads are connected. Critical loads are required to have backup power per AFMAN 32-1062. This strategy does not include UPS systems, which are captured in Strategy 9, Critical Load UPS System.

Strategy / Capability: Backup Power for Other Loads / HVAC (Building Level)
Action: Install Backup Power for Other Loads / HVAC (Building Level)
Description: Backup power systems should be fully functional when required. Backup power for loads that are beyond the loads required in AFMAN 32-1062, which may include mission-specified loads, reduces mission degradation. For example, while sustaining HVAC loads may not be required, doing so may improve mission function.

Action: Install/Upsize UPS System (Building Level)
Description: Some critical loads, such as server racks, require uninterrupted power. The goal of this strategy is to install or upsize a UPS to adequately serve critical loads.

Action: Install Portable Backup Power Tie-in Connection (Building Level)
Description: A quick-connect port connects mobile generators to mission-essential loads as designated by the installation. Even if a mission is not authorized for an Equipment Authorized Inventory Data (EAID) generator under AFMAN 32-1062, a facility can install a quick-connect to the switchboard, especially if the facility is being designed or renovated.

Action: Centralize Backup Power (District Level)
Description: Backup power systems should be fully functional when required. Centralizing backup power systems at the district level helps realize improved operations and maintenance (O&M) and fuel efficiencies. An example is a cluster of buildings that all require backup power, and each one has significantly oversized and/or redundant generators. Note that centralized generators are typically designed to operate for longer runtimes than facility-level generators.

Action: Install Centralized Dual-fuel Backup Power (District Level)
Description: Backup power systems should be fully functional when required. Centralizing backup power systems at the district level helps realize improved O&M and fuel efficiencies, and enabling generators to run on two or more fuel types (e.g., diesel, natural gas) increases flexibility for providing backup power in the event of a disruption to the fuel supply. Note that Jet Propellant 8 (JP-8) is not considered a dual fuel for diesel because using JP-8 requires modifying fuel injectors and because the extended use of JP-8 requires modifying maintenance schedules.

Strategy / Capability: Backup Power Conversion to Dual-fuel (District Level)
Action: Convert Existing Backup Power to Dual-fuel (District Level)
Description: Generators that can run on two or more fuel types (e.g., diesel, natural gas) have greater flexibility than single-fuel generators in providing backup power if the fuel supply is disrupted. The goal of this strategy is to ensure that generators covering critical facility loads at the district level have the capability to use multiple fuel types. Note that Jet Propellant 8 (JP-8) is not considered a dual fuel for diesel because using JP-8 requires modifying fuel injectors and because the extended use of JP-8 requires modifying maintenance schedules.

Action: Establish Priority Generator Fueling Protocol
Description: In an installation-wide and long-term outage, all generators across the base will need regular refueling. A refueling schedule would allow tracking how often each generator needs to be refueled. Additionally, prioritizing generators can determine which ones need to stay fueled at all times and which ones can run dry if refueling capabilities are constrained due to equipment, workforce, or fuel supply shortages.

Action: Test Generators Using Full Existing Loads (Installation Level)
Description: When generators are tested, the full critical load (circuit or building) should be tested. Loads should not be shed during tests, and tests should not be conducted during off-hours. Load banks can be installed in generators that are large enough for load banks and can be used to test the full capacity of the generator beyond the critical load to help ensure that the generators are reliable for the required full load. This strategy applies to centralized generators at the district level.

Action: Conduct Generator Hard-Drop Testing (Installation Level)
Description: During an outage or emergency, the backup power for a district should be reliable and function properly. Testing backup power by cutting utility power to the installation can determine whether the power transfer systems work correctly and whether all critical loads are properly connected to the backup power. This strategy applies to centralized generators at the district level.

Action: Connect Backup Power Source for Fuel Pumps
Description: Fuel pumps may be in place for pumping fuel from bulk storage to aircraft or fleet or for generator refueling. These fueling operations may be considered critical operations and, if so, would need backup power so the operations could be sustained through an outage.

Action: Install Backup Power for Security Assets (Building Level)
Description: Security assets should have a reliable source of power even during unpredictable events. Backup power systems ensure that supply failure does not compromise uninterruptable security assets or functions, such as installation gates and perimeter security systems.

Action: Procure/Increase Diesel Refueling Truck Capacity
Description: In an installation-wide and long-term outage, refueling capabilities can be constrained by a lack of refueling equipment or a refueling prioritization plan, resulting in failure of backup power or heating systems. Procuring additional fueling trucks and/or increasing the capacity of existing equipment would resolve inadequate refueling capabilities.

Action: Procure Portable Backup Power Generators
Description: The installation should have an adequate inventory of portable generators to meet its needs. Facilities should have connection points ready to receive a portable generator (Strategy 10, Portable Generator Quick-Connect (Building Level)). The number of available portable generators across the installation should be verified to be adequate for loads that would benefit from backup power capability but that do not qualify for real property generators.

Action: Mitigate Single Points of Failure (Backup Power)
Description: Backup power systems can have a single point of failure. For example, a redundant generator but only one UPS is a single point of failure and represents a degradation of power availability. Requiring redundancy through all stages of the backup power system ensures that there are no single points of failure associated with the provision of backup power.

Action: Change the Type of Cooling Generation Source (Building Level)
Description: A building may only have one source of cooling energy during an outage. Establishing an alternate source of cooling energy at a building level reduces reliance on one type of system during an outage. For example, in the server room, a computer room air conditioning (CRAC) system can operate as a backup system for the room as well as potentially for the building by leaving the server door open.

Action: Change the Type of Heat Generation Source (Building Level)
Description: A building may only have one source of heating fuel energy during an outage. Diversifying the heating fuel source reduces reliance on a single supply line or system. This strategy includes installing or upgrading building heating systems to work with multiple fuels or systems (e.g., installing both a natural gas boiler system and electric heating for localized critical loads).

Action: Add Physical Protection to Electrical Distribution Components (Installation Level)
Description: Certain components of electrical distribution systems (e.g., switches, transformers) may be at risk of physical damage from day-to-day activities at an installation. This strategy involves placing physical protection around these components to prevent accidental damage by, for example, installing ground-level transfer switches that can be protected by bollards to prevent damage from vehicles.

Action: Simplify HVAC Systems (Reduced Component Failure)
Description: Some facilities have undergone ad hoc retrofits over many years, resulting in an assortment of HVAC system types and ages that serve different zones. Simplifying and consolidating systems can reduce the number of vulnerable components and reduce O&M costs.

Action: Install Thermal Energy Storage (Building Level)
Description: Buildings are subject to outages during unpredictable events. Having the capability to store thermal energy (e.g., ice, chilled water, hot water storage) at the building level can provide backup supply during outages and be used to reduce peak load, save energy costs, and reduce the design requirements for primary and backup power, helping the facility reach its required sustainment capacity.

Strategy / Capability: Cooling Capacity for Critical Loads (Building Level)
Action: Increase Cooling System Capacity (Building Level)
Description: Insufficient cooling capacity for critical loads, especially during heat waves, can make work environments nonviable for personnel and can damage equipment. Ensuring that the facility’s HVAC system has sufficient cooling capacity helps meet all facility critical cooling loads (e.g., servers, critical personnel, process cooling).

Strategy / Capability: Heating Capacity for Critical Loads (Building Level)
Action: Increase Heating System Capacity (Building Level)
Description: Insufficient heating capacity for critical loads, especially during cold spells, can make work environments nonviable for personnel and can damage equipment. Ensuring that the facility’s HVAC system has sufficient heating capacity helps meet all facility critical heating loads (e.g. climate controlled storage, critical personnel, process heating).

Strategy / Capability: Water Intrusion and Flood Risk Mitigation (Building Level)
Action: Raise or Relocate Critical Equipment (Building Level)
Description: Buildings are susceptible to flood damage. Locating critical equipment below expected flood levels (e.g., in a basement) can increase the likelihood of water damage. Additionally, water intrusion through the building envelope during rain events can damage critical equipment such as servers. Water intrusion through storm/sanitary sewer drain blockages can further cause mission disruption if sewage backs up into sensitive equipment or critical operations rooms. Raising the elevation of critical equipment to above the expected flood level and addressing critical water intrusion issues can avoid such damage.

Strategy / Capability: Portable HVAC System Tie-in Connection (Building Level)
Action: Install Portable HVAC System Tie-in Connection (Building Level)
Description: If a facility has a critical heating or cooling load, providing a backup heating or cooling system will ensure that the loads can be met in case of equipment or system failure. If a load is not deemed so critical that it requires a permanent backup system but equipment failure would cause mission degradation, enabling a tie-in connection for a portable backup system (such as a chiller or boiler) can provide sufficient redundancy at lower cost.

Action: Procure Portable Backup HVAC Systems (Building Level)
Description: The required capacity of building HVAC systems varies. Portable HVAC systems such as chillers and boilers of different sizes can adequately meet the variable capacity demands across the installation. Portable HVAC systems require a portable HVAC system tie-in.

Strategy / Capability: Dedicated Electrical Circuit for Critical Loads (Building Level)
Action: Install a Dedicated Electrical Circuit for Critical Loads (Building Level)
Description: Critical loads of a building must be met during unpredictable events. Dedicating an electrical circuit for critical loads in a facility can enable the isolation of critical loads when providing backup power. If not all loads within a facility are critical, configuring the backup power system so it powers just the critical circuits can lower the required sustainment capacity and extend the time frame during which loads can be supported in an outage.

Strategy / Capability: Redundant HVAC Systems for Critical Loads (Building Level)
Action: Install Redundant HVAC Systems for Critical Loads (Building Level)
Description: If a facility has a critical heating or cooling load, ensuring redundancy in the heating or cooling system can mitigate the impact of equipment or source failure. For example, installing extra CRAC units provides redundant cooling capacity in a critical server room.

Action: Change the Type of Cooling Generation Source (District Level)
Description: A district may have only one source of cooling energy during an outage. Establishing an alternate source of cooling energy at the district level reduces reliance on one type of system during an outage (e.g., capturing wasted cooling from LNG or propane storage, natural gas / steam adsorption chillers as an alternative to electric chillers).

Action: Change the Type of Heat Generation Source (District Level)
Description: A district may have only one source of heating fuel energy during an outage. Diversifying the heating fuel source reduces reliance on a single supply line. This strategy includes installing or upgrading heating systems at the district level that can operate with multiple fuels or systems (for example, installing electric heat pumps and boilers that can operate on both natural and propane gas).

Action: Install a Centralized District-level Cooling System (District Level)
Description: A centralized cooling system consists of a central plant that generates chilled water that serves connected facilities. Centralizing cooling systems at a district level can improve redundancy for critical loads when coupled with a localized cooling source. Centralizing cooling systems also consolidates and reduces the primary equipment that must be maintained, potentially easing preventative maintenance and reducing the critical sustainment capacity requirement.

Action: Install a Centralized District-level Heating System (District Level)
Description: A centralized heating system consists of a central plant that generates hot water or steam that serves connected facilities. Centralizing heating systems at a district level can improve redundancy when coupled with a localized heating source. Centralizing heating systems also consolidates and reduces the primary equipment that must be maintained, potentially easing preventative maintenance and reducing the critical sustainment capacity requirement.

Action: Install Thermal Energy Storage (District Level)
Description: Buildings are subject to outages during unpredictable events. Having the capability to store thermal energy (e.g., ice, chilled water, hot water storage) can provide backup supply during an outage and also be used to reduce peak load, save energy costs, reduce peak capacity requirements, and help the facility reach its required sustainment capacity. This strategy requires a centralized cooling or heating system at the district level.

Action: Increase Cooling System Capacity (District Level)
Description: Having a centralized cooling system with sufficient capacity increases the available cooling supply in the event of a localized equipment fault.

Action: Increase Heating System Capacity (District Level)
Description: Having a centralized heating system with sufficient capacity increases the available heating supply in the event of a localized equipment fault.

Action: Change the Type of Cooling Generation Source (Installation Level)
Description: Installations are subject to outages during unpredictable events. Establishing an alternate source of cooling energy at an installation level reduces reliance on one type of system during an event (e.g., capturing wasted cooling from LNG or propane storage, natural gas / steam adsorption chillers as an alternative to electric chillers). An alternate source of cooling energy is applicable only if the installation is served by one or more central cooling plants.

Action: Change the Type of Heat Generation Source (Installation Level)
Description: Installations are subject to outages during unpredictable events. Diversifying the heating fuel source reduces reliance on a single supply line or system. This strategy includes installing or upgrading heating systems across the installation that operate with multiple fuels (for example, installing electric heat pumps and boilers that can operate on both natural and propane gas).

Action: Install a Centralized Installation-level Cooling System (Installation Level)
Description: A centralized cooling system consists of a central plant that generates chilled water that serves connected facilities. Centralizing cooling systems at an installation level can improve redundancy for critical loads when coupled with localized cooling sources. Centralizing cooling systems also consolidates and reduces the primary equipment that must be maintained, potentially easing preventative maintenance and reducing the critical sustainment capacity requirement.

Action: Install a Centralized Installation-level Heating System (Installation Level)
Description: A centralized heating system consists of a central plant that generates hot water or steam that serves connected facilities. Centralizing heating systems at an installation level can improve redundancy when coupled with localized heating sources. Centralizing heating systems also consolidates and reduces the primary equipment that must be maintained, potentially easing preventative maintenance and reducing the critical sustainment capacity requirement.

Action: Install Alternative Communications Connection or System
Description: Building communications systems are subject to failure during unpredictable events. Establishing alternate communications routes for energy systems provides a backup control route if a primary system is compromised.

Action: Install Systems Monitoring Equipment
Description: Monitoring a building’s energy system performance allows localized response to issues and optimization opportunities. Monitoring can identify equipment that is compromised and resources whose consumption could be reduced.

Strategy / Capability: Energy Management and Control Systems (EMCS) (Building Level)
Action: Install/Expand Energy Management Control Systems (Building Level)
Description: Rapid response time and sustainment of critical loads of buildings must be consistent. Installing an EMCS allows monitoring and controlling energy systems at a building level, which can enhance response time to system issues and increase sustainment time by curtailing noncritical loads.

Action: Isolate Communications Strands / Zones
Description: Isolating energy communications networks from other base communications networks improves the security of both. If one system is compromised, the separation can protect the other. This strategy focuses on the segregation of SCADA/energy systems from the rest of the base communications network to mitigate hacking vulnerability. Virtual Local Area Networks (VLANs) are acceptable, such as a Community of Interest Network Enclave (COINE) network.

Action: Establish a Priority Load-shedding Protocol
Description: If the installation is facing a power outage or energy supply shortage, critical energy demands will need to be met while noncritical demands can be shed. This strategy involves prioritizing critical energy demands to establish an order in which loads can be shed in the event of limited electricity supply.

Action: Establish a Centralized EOC
Description: During an unpredictable event, critical personnel should have an established centralized location for the active monitoring of system data and response coordination, which would be in an EOC that is staffed 24/7/365. For the monitoring to be fully effective, a base-wide SCADA system is required.

Action: Encrypt Communications Network
Description: Installations are subject to cyberattacks. Adding sufficient encryption to the energy communications networks allows additional protection from cyberattacks.

Action: Install/Upgrade Base-Wide SCADA System (Energy)
Description: SCADA systems for energy allow personnel to monitor and, if necessary, operate all of the installation’s energy systems from a single terminal and/or remotely. SCADA systems can reduce workforce needs, allow rapid identification of equipment failures, and speed recovery from failures. SCADA systems require appropriate cybersecurity measures.

Action: Assign Personnel to Energy Management Duties
Description: Energy management systems help ensure that critical energy loads are sustained throughout the installation. Assigning personnel to monitor and review data from energy management systems and respond to identified issues improves system efficiency and reliability. This strategy is more effective when combined with installation-level management and control systems.

Action: Mitigate Single Points of Failure (Communications)
Description: A single point of failure in the communications system means that failure at one point causes disruption to all downstream nodes. This strategy includes looping all communications lines that come from the base communications hub, interconnecting information transfer nodes, providing redundant conduits, and using other strategies that enable alternate communications routes if an element of the system fails.

Action: Implement Building Envelope Sealing Strategies (Building Level)
Description: Building envelope conditions can have a significant impact on the HVAC energy demand for a facility and during outages and can lengthen or shorten the amount time before personnel must evacuate the facility because of diminished thermal comfort (i.e., temperature drop or rise). Sealing the facility envelope reduces the flow of outdoor air seeping in through cracks and joints (e.g., doors, window frames) and corresponding required conditioning.

Action: Upgrade HVAC Equipment to Increase Performance (Building Level)
Description: Facilities are commonly found to have underperforming HVAC systems (heating and/or cooling). During normal operation, underperformance can cause mission degradation when certain zones are outside the required thermal range but must be occupied or are required for equipment operation. During outage conditions, any underperforming HVAC systems that are powered by backup systems may consume more energy than needed. Upgrading HVAC systems can improve mission performance and reduce backup power requirements.

Action: Upgrade Lighting to Increase Performance (Building Level)
Description: Reducing total electricity demand reduces the critical electricity demand, which in turn increases the sustainment capacity of existing backup power capacity and lowers the cost of proposed backup power capacity (both in terms of capacity and energy storage duration). Upgrading lighting (e.g., replacing fluorescent lamps with light-emitting diode [LED] lamps) can cost-effectively reduce electricity demand.

Action: Implement Plug Load Management Strategies (Building Level)
Description: Backup power systems may power noncritical loads, which would decrease sustainment duration during outages. Managing and reducing plug load demand at a building level can increase sustainment duration during outages. This strategy includes installing switches at the equipment or circuit level to allow load shedding when required.

Action: Recommission Buildings (Building Level)
Description: Over time, a facility’s HVAC equipment settings can deviate from the initial facility commissioning settings. Recommissioning the facility periodically (e.g., every 5 years) includes restoring the initial settings and making additional adjustments to the equipment, both of which can reduce energy demand and lengthen equipment lifespan at relatively low cost. Rebalancing a facility includes ensuring that the correct thermal flow is reaching the correct loads, especially if a facility has been repurposed from its original design. Rebalancing includes reducing or adding new controls and monitors where needed.

Action: Implement Energy Retrofit Projects
Description: An installation’s energy performance should be improved if deficiencies are identified in order to optimize the consumption of resources. Energy retrofits such as installing better controls and scheduling, motor upgrades, and variable frequency drives on fans and pumps can improve energy performance. Reducing energy demand and improving control mitigate the strain on energy resources, thus improving critical load sustainment capacity and reducing the need for system capacity upgrades.

Action: Establish Energy Management Protocol
Description: Powering noncritical loads throughout the installation can decrease the amount of time that power is sustained during outages. Adopting installation-wide procedures that concentrate on reducing resource use increases the sustainment period during outage events. Following an independent third-party-validated energy management protocol such as ISO 50001, Energy Management, can benefit consistency and quality in the application of installation-wide procedures. Procedures can include a clearly defined response to identified system performance issues and energy education for tenants. This strategy is more effective if implemented in conjunction with an EMCS.

Action: Implement Electricity Demand Forecasting
Description: Forecasting energy demand allows for proactive adjustment to system operation and resource allocation to ensure energy cost-effectiveness. Establishing an effective mitigation plan can reduce identified gaps between forecasted load and available resources. Operationalizing energy resources for load balancing and islanding is captured in Strategies 116 and 127 (District Microgrid and Installation Microgrid, respectively).

Action: Install a Peaker Plant for Energy Demand Management
Description: Installations may want backup power but may not be able to secure financing to acquire it. Installing a peaker plant can provide cost savings to the installation and increase sustainment power capacity. Peaker plant generators are typically operated intermittently to reduce load on utility transmission lines, especially during peak times with high energy costs. This strategy focuses on energy cost savings but can be operationalized to provide power to critical installation loads during outages through a combination with other strategies such as Strategy 79 (Access to Alternate/Renewable Generation during an Outage) or Strategy 127 (Installation Microgrid).

Strategy / Capability: Energy Management and Control Systems (EMCS) (Installation Level)
Action: Install/Expand Energy Management and Control Systems (Including Data Logging)
Description: Rapid response time and sustainment of an installation’s critical loads must be consistent. An EMCS allows monitoring and control of energy systems at the installation level at every major facility and can enhance response time to system issues and increase sustainment time by curtailing noncritical loads.

Action: Install Submetering on Power Systems (Installation Level)
Description: Power systems should be able to consistently sustain building energy demands. Monitoring a building’s energy system performance allows localized response to issues and optimization opportunities. This strategy identifies equipment that is compromised and resources whose consumption could be reduced. This strategy focuses on power monitoring at an installation level (master meters) and building-level meters across installation facilities.

Action: Install Energy Storage (Building Level)
Description: Buildings are subject to an outage during unpredictable events. Having the capability to store electrical energy (e.g., battery backup) at the building level can provide power during an outage and reduce the peak demand of the facility during “blue-sky” conditions. Backup power can help the facility sustain critical operations and extend the fuel supply for backup generators. Reducing peak demand can reduce utility energy costs and lower the peak design requirements for facility infrastructure.

Action: Add/Increase Fuel Storage Capacity (Building Level)
Description: In a widespread and prolonged outage, the installation may face constrained refueling of generators. Ensuring adequate on-site storage of fuel (in most cases diesel) can help the facility sustain power supply during prolonged outages and when there are potential shortages in diesel supply.

Action: Install Energy Storage (District Level)
Description: Providing backup power at a district level may serve more facilities more effectively than providing backup power at the building level. If the district-level electrical infrastructure is configured appropriately, installing battery energy storage at a district substation to serve a group of buildings at the district level can be a more effective way to supply backup power than at the building level. For example, an energy storage system can provide backup power to a district substation and energize all feeds served by that substation from a single location.

Action: Add/Increase Centralized Fuel Storage Capacity (District Level)
Description: Diesel fuel storage may be appropriate for districts that are pursuing backup generation at the district level. Installing district-level storage can be an effective supplement to installation-level fuel storage and provide additional sustainment capacity to facilities during a widespread and/or prolonged outage. This strategy can be particularly effective, for example, in a district with facilities with high backup power loads, high diesel consumption rates, and/or off-base diesel refueling contracts.

Strategy / Capability: Centralized Heating Fuel Storage Capacity (Installation Level)
Action: Add/Increase Centralized Heating Fuel Storage Capacity (Installation Level)
Description: Fuel supply that originates off base may be cut off during an outage. An installation-level backup heating fuel supply during a regional outage at bases where heating is a critical energy demand can increase the sustainment period. Increasing on-site storage can mitigate supply availability risk and can be accomplished at an installation level by, for example, installing one or more storage tanks at a location that is accessible by all critical facilities.

Action: Install Energy Storage (Installation Level)
Description: Installing electrical energy storage at a primary substation can serve the entire installation. If the electrical infrastructure is configured appropriately, battery energy storage at the installation level can be a more effective way to supply backup power than at the building level and can also be used for demand management during normal operations and to provide cost savings. This strategy can be operationalized for load balancing and islanding by adding Strategy 127 (Installation Microgrid).

Action: Add/Increase Centralized Fuel Storage Capacity (Installation Level)
Description: Fuel supply, including diesel, propane, and LNG, that originates off base can be disrupted during a regional event. Sustaining the power supply from backup generators in an extended outage requires a steady supply of fuel (in most instances diesel). Increasing on-site fuel storage can mitigate supply availability risk and can be accomplished at an installation level by, for example, installing one or more storage tanks at a location that is accessible for all critical facilities.

Action: Install Alternative/Renewable Energy Generation (Building Level)
Description: Traditional energy sources (e.g., diesel, gas, coal) rely on supply chains and may be subject to failure. Alternate/renewable energy reduces reliance on upstream supply chains and can continue to provide electricity even when there is a disruption to the conventional supply. Installing alternate/‌‌renewable energy at the building level can help improve facility sustainment capacity for critical loads and offset reliance on diesel supply. Additionally, alternate/renewable energy can lower utility energy costs for the installation. Examples of building-level alternate/renewable energy are solar photovoltaic (PV) and fuel cells. Operationalizing energy generation for load balancing and islanding is captured in Strategies 116 and 127 (District Microgrid and Installation Microgrid, respectively).

Action: Install Alternative/Renewable Energy Generation (District Level)
Description: Traditional energy sources (e.g., diesel, natural gas, coal) rely on supply chains and may be subject to failure. Alternate/renewable energy reduces reliance on upstream supply chains. Configuring district-level electrical infrastructure allows alternate/renewable energy to help power the entire district during a grid power outage, reducing reliance on diesel supply for critical power loads, and lowering utility energy costs for the installation. Examples of district-level alternate/renewable energy are solar PV, fuel cells, waste-to-energy plants, wind turbines, and combined heat and power. Operationalizing energy generation for load balancing and islanding is captured in Strategies 116 and 127 (District Microgrid and Installation Microgrid, respectively).

Action: Install Alternative/Renewable Energy Generation (Installation Level)
Description: Traditional energy sources (e.g., diesel, gas, coal) rely on supply chains and may be subject to failure. Installing alternate/renewable energy offsets reliance on upstream supply chains. Additionally, alternate/renewable energy can lower utility energy costs for the installation. Examples of installation-level alternate/renewable energy include solar PV and wind turbines. Operationalizing energy generation for load balancing and islanding is captured in Strategies 116 and 127 (District Microgrid and Installation Microgrid, respectively).

Action: Establish Redundant Fuel Supply Routes (Installation Level)
Description: If the installation has on-base fuel-supply infrastructure (e.g., pipelines between storage areas), installing redundant on-site fuel supply routes provides an alternate supply path in case the primary supply is disrupted.

Action: Mitigate Single Points of Failure / Loop Lines (Fuel)
Description: A single point of failure in the fuel supply means that failure at one point causes disruption to all demand downstream. This strategy may include, for example, a redundant storage tank, redundant supply pipelines (if present), looped fuel delivery lines, and fuel pumps.

Action: Mitigate Single Points of Failure / Loop Lines (Gas)
Description: A single point of failure in the natural gas supply means that failure at one point causes disruption to all downstream service. Configuring the gas supply to be able to reroute mitigates the impact of single points of failure. Examples are interconnected systems (i.e., ability to back feed) and looped configuration (i.e., no dead ends).

Strategy / Capability: Access to Alternate/Renewable Generation during an Outage
Action: Remove Barriers to Alternative On-Site Generation
Description: Installations may have alternate/renewable energy systems available on site or nearby, but they may not be operated in such a way that allows the installation to use them directly. Removing administrative or technical barriers can allow the full use of existing alternate or renewable on-site generation assets (e.g., establishing agreements and modifying circuits to allow existing utility-owned alternate generation to serve the installation during an outage).

Action: Install Alternative/Renewable Energy Generation (Off Site)
Description: Traditional energy sources (e.g., diesel, natural gas, coal) rely on supply chains and may be subject to failure. Installing alternate/renewable energy mitigates reliance on upstream supply chains and can continue to provide facility sustainment capacity even during a wider grid outage. Additionally, alternate/renewable energy can lower utility energy costs for the installation. Examples of off-site alternate/renewable energy are biogas, solar PV, wind turbines, and small-scale hydroelectric power.

Action: Establish Redundant Fuel Supply Routes (Off-Site Level)
Description: Off-site supply routes are subject to disruption and cannot sustain critical loads until the primary supply is restored. Providing a redundant fuel supply route from off site to the installation can help mitigate this issue. For example, an installation may be able to supply fuel via truck, rail, or barge. A redundant fuel supply route can include additional infrastructure, availability guarantees in contracts, or alternate fuel contractors.

Strategy / Capability: Preventative Maintenance for Heating and Cooling Equipment (Building Level)
Action: Conduct Preventative Maintenance for Heating and Cooling Equipment (Building Level)
Description: While workforce constraints can limit an installation’s capacity for preventative maintenance of infrastructure systems, deferring maintenance increases the likelihood that systems or components will fail before the end of their design useful life and compromise critical resource supply. Preventative maintenance, which includes routine procedures before components fail, can significantly enhance the lifespan and lifecycle performance of the equipment. This strategy is applicable to heating and cooling systems at the building level.

Strategy / Capability: Preventative Maintenance for Heating and Cooling Equipment (District Level)
Action: Conduct Preventative Maintenance for Heating and Cooling Equipment (District Level)
Description: While workforce constraints can limit an installation’s capacity for preventative maintenance of infrastructure systems, deferring maintenance increases the likelihood that systems or components will fail before the end of their useful design life and compromise critical resource supply. Preventative maintenance, which includes routine maintenance before components fail, can significantly enhance the lifespan and lifecycle performance of equipment. The strategy is applicable to heating and cooling systems at the district level.

Strategy / Capability: Preventative Maintenance for Power Systems (District Level)
Action: Conduct Preventative Maintenance for Power Systems (District Level)
Description: While workforce constraints can limit an installation’s capacity for preventative maintenance of infrastructure systems, deferring maintenance increases the likelihood that systems or components will fail before the end of their useful design life and compromise critical resource supply. Preventative maintenance, which includes routine maintenance before components fail, can significantly enhance the lifespan and lifecycle performance of equipment. This strategy is applicable to power systems at the district level.

Strategy / Capability: Preventative Maintenance for Water Systems (District Level)
Action: Conduct Preventative Maintenance for Water Systems (District Level)
Description: While workforce constraints can limit an installation’s capacity for preventative maintenance of infrastructure systems, deferring maintenance increases the likelihood that systems or components will fail before the end of their useful design life and compromise critical resource supply. Preventative maintenance, which includes routine maintenance before components fail, can significantly enhance the lifespan and lifecycle performance of equipment. This strategy is applicable to water systems at the district level.

Action: Establish an Operations, Maintenance and Testing (OM&T) Protocol
Description: The safety and reliability of a power system depends largely on its OM&T strategy. This strategy includes the development of an installation-specific, comprehensive OM&T protocol for energy resilience systems and infrastructure as outlined in Energy Resilience: Operations, Maintenance, & Testing (OM&T) Strategy and Implementation Guidance from the Office of the Assistant Secretary of Defense (DoD, 2017b).

Action: Implement a UPS Maintenance and Testing Protocol
Description: Some UPSs fail during an outage as a result of the lack of a clear maintenance and testing protocol. Currently, most UPS maintenance and testing protocols are established by the mission owner the UPS is supporting, but clarity on responsibility may be lacking. This strategy involves establishing responsibility and clear protocols for maintenance and testing of all UPSs at the installation level such that none are unintentionally overlooked.

Action: Install an Alternative Wastewater Connection
Description: An alternate domestic wastewater connection includes a connection to a nearby municipal wastewater treatment system. For installations relying exclusively on on-base treatment systems, implementing this strategy can ensure continued access to wastewater treatment in the event of failure.

Action: Train Personnel to Be Able to Identify the Source of Power Disruption
Description: When a power system fails, the top priority is to repair it and restore power to critical functions. If the cause of the failure is not determined, the system may fail again. Addressing the need to determine the cause of a power system failure allows corrections to be made proactively at the source rather than reactively at the failure point.

Strategy / Capability: Personnel Training to Achieve Redundant Expertise
Action: Provide Training to Personnel to Achieve Redundant Expertise
Description: Effective maintenance and repair of energy systems are critical to ensuring that the systems operate as intended in an outage. The required expertise for this work is often limited to a small number of individuals. This strategy consists of implementing training and hiring practices to ensure that the expertise is available in case the personnel with primary responsibility are unavailable.

Strategy / Capability: Preventative Maintenance for Heating and Cooling Equipment (Installation Level)
Action: Conduct Preventative Maintenance for Heating and Cooling Equipment (Installation Level)
Description: While workforce constraints can limit an installation’s capacity for preventative maintenance of infrastructure systems, deferring maintenance increases the likelihood that systems or components will fail before the end of their design useful life and compromise critical resource supply. Preventative maintenance, which includes routine maintenance before components fail, can significantly enhance the lifespan and lifecycle performance of equipment. This strategy is applicable to heating and cooling systems at the installation level.

Strategy / Capability: Preventative Maintenance for Power Systems (Installation Level)
Action: Conduct Preventative Maintenance for Power Systems (Installation Level)
Description: While workforce constraints can limit an installation’s capacity for preventative maintenance of infrastructure systems, deferring maintenance increases the likelihood that systems or components will fail before the end of their useful design life and compromise critical resource supply. Preventative maintenance, which includes routine maintenance before components fail, can significantly enhance the lifespan and lifecycle performance of equipment. This strategy is applicable to power systems at the installation level.

Strategy / Capability: Preventative Maintenance for Water Systems (Installation Level)
Action: Conduct Preventative Maintenance for Water Systems (Installation Level)
Description: While workforce constraints can limit an installation’s capacity for preventative maintenance of infrastructure systems, deferring maintenance increases the likelihood that systems or components will fail before the end of their useful design life and compromise critical resource supply. Preventative maintenance, which includes routine maintenance before components fail, can significantly enhance the lifespan and lifecycle performance of equipment. This strategy is applicable to water systems at the installation level.

Strategy / Capability: Provision of Master Access Keys to Repair Teams
Action: Provide Master Access Keys to Repair Teams
Description: Response and repair teams play an important role in responding to unpredictable events and assessing buildings after an event. Ensuring that the teams have access to facilities during recovery helps ensure that damage assessments are comprehensive and can help reduce recovery time after an outage.

Action: Maintain On-site Inventory of Critical and Limited Spare Parts
Description: Replacement parts for critical equipment can have long lead times for delivery or may no longer be available from the manufacturer. Maintaining an inventory of common replacement parts on site can significantly reduce repair and recovery times in a disruption. When applicable, an inventory can leverage central command structure between multiple installations to share stockpiles of common components.

Action: Standardize Replacement Parts
Description: Specialized replacement parts for critical equipment can have long lead times for delivery or may no longer be available from the manufacturer. Ensuring that equipment is using standard parts whenever possible can significantly reduce repair and recovery times in an event.

Strategy / Capability: Graceful or Phased Shutdown Procedures (Building Level)
Action: Establish Graceful Shutdown Procedures (Building Level)
Description: During an unpredictable event, shutdown may be activated, but shutdown procedures may not have been established. For missions that can safely relocate or reduce operations in an outage, establishing graceful shutdown procedures (also called “phased” or “staged” shutdown procedures) can conserve resources and minimize damage to equipment. This strategy involves establishing graceful shutdown procedures at the building level if they do not exist.

Action: Adopt Standardized Cybersecurity Authorization Protocol
Description: Many strategies that improve energy resilience also increase the vulnerability of infrastructure systems to cyberattacks. This strategy focuses on adopting a standard procedure for all projects to ensure that they are compliant with all cybersecurity requirements.

Strategy / Capability: Centralized Damage Assessment Database (Digital or Hardcopy)
Action: Create a Centralized Damage Assessment Database
Description: Recovery efforts can be hampered by incomplete or conflicting damage assessment data. Centralizing the assessment database can allow all personnel to use the same data/format and more effectively contribute to recovery efforts.

Strategy / Capability: Defined Repair and Recovery Communication Protocols
Action: Establish Defined Repair and Recovery Communication Protocols
Description: Effective communication is critical to the success of a disaster response team. This strategy involves clearly defining the alternate communication methods and their priority in the development of a communication protocol.

Strategy / Capability: Graceful or Phased Shutdown Procedures (Installation Level)
Action: Establish Graceful Shutdown Procedures (Installation Level)
Description: During an unpredictable event, shutdown may be activated, but shutdown procedures may not have been established. For missions that can safely relocate or reduce operations in an outage, establishing graceful shutdown procedures (also called “phased” or “staged” shutdown procedures) can conserve resources and minimize damage to equipment. This strategy involves establishing graceful shutdown procedures at the installation level if they do not exist.

Strategy / Capability: Multidisciplinary Disaster Assistance Response Teams (DARTs) Using Standardized Checklists
Action: Establish Multidisciplinary DARTs Using Standardized Checklists
Description: DARTs conduct preliminary damage assessments after an event. Using multidisciplinary teams (e.g., electrical, civil, and mechanical engineers) and developing standardized checklists can streamline recovery efforts and maximize the quality of assessments.

Strategy / Capability: Remote Alerts for Critical Infrastructure Assets
Action: Enable Remote Alerts for Infrastructure Assets
Description: Alerts are not always distributed quickly and/or to appropriate personnel during a disruption. Remote alerts enable personnel to monitor critical infrastructure and also identify and respond to system issues more quickly and directly than localized alerts. Alerts should be tied to a cybersecure centralized monitoring station (such as the Base Defense Operations Center [BDOC]), reducing the recovery time from a disruption.

Strategy / Capability: Repair and EOC Shift Alignment and Coordination
Action: Coordinate and Align Repair and EOC Shifts
Description: Aligning the EOC and repair teams’ schedules can streamline communications and improve coordination during recovery efforts.

Strategy / Capability: Power and Fuel Line Vulnerability/Resiliency Assessment
Action: Conduct a Power, Water, and Fuel Line Vulnerability Assessment
Description: Infrastructure systems may sometimes have a single point of failure that is unassessed. Conducting a comprehensive vulnerability/resiliency assessment of energy infrastructure can identify potential weaknesses that need to be resolved to ensure mission sustainment during outages. The results of the assessment should guide future work to improve the resiliency of power and fuel systems.

Action: Procure Deployable Emergency Pipeline
Description: Critical loads may not be sustained during an outage because of insufficient water or fuel delivery. When the mission capability exists on base, ensuring that a deployable fuel or water emergency pipeline is available can support delivery to critical loads in an outage.

Action: Update Fuel Procurement Contracts
Description: Existing base fuel delivery contracts may not include a guarantee of delivery or prioritized customer status. This strategy aims to add language to the procurement contract to ensure availability of fuel during a local event or shortage.

Action: Establish Contractor Emergency Availability Protocol (Energy)
Description: If some or all of an installation’s energy infrastructure is privatized, the contract or other supporting documentation should include provisions for the contractor’s responsibility in emergencies. This strategy includes specified response times to failures and priority status in disaster response.

Strategy / Capability: Alternate to Air Force Instruction (AFI) Critical Facility Mandate
Action: Alternative to AFI Critical Facility Mandate
Description: Existing AFI requirements for assigning generators as real property do not consider some critical assets (e.g., gate facilities). In addition, generator sizing guidelines do not always allow the comfort HVAC system load to be considered critical and thus served by a backup generator. However, in some locations (e.g., Alaska), HVAC is critical to personnel safety and mission sustainment. Identifying an alternate compliance route or exemptions when warranted can address these gaps and considerations.

Action: Exceptions to Allow Single-Source Procurement
Description: A wide variety of manufacturers of a given type of equipment can make it difficult to keep personnel sufficiently trained on operation, maintenance, and procurement of spare/replacement parts. For some equipment (e.g., generators), insufficient training degrades recoverability by contributing to the frequency and duration of equipment failure. This strategy resolves these challenges by exempting multi-manufacturer procurement requirements for certain types of equipment.

Action: Repair Existing Electrical Distribution Circuits (Building Level)
Description: A facility may have an inadequate electrical circuit condition if areas within the building face repeated circuit breaker openings or exhibit other power reliability issues, including fire concern. Repairing electrical circuits in poor condition improves reliability and reduces the likelihood of mission degradation. Repair may include replacing all building circuits, breakers, transformers, switches, relays, fuses, and other safety devices before the equipment is 40 years old.

Action: Mitigate Single Points of Failure / Loop Lines (Power)
Description: A single point of failure in the electrical circuits at the building level means that failure at one point causes disruption to all downstream loads. At the building level, a single point of failure can be a single breaker panel, single transformer, or lone circuit serving critical loads. This strategy requires installing an alternate supply route or additional equipment.

Action: Connect Redundant Electrical Feeder (Building Level)
Description: A primary feeder can be subject to failure during unpredictable events. Installing a redundant electrical feeder to a facility (preferably from a separate substation) allows power to be sustained when there is a failure in the primary feeder. A redundant electrical feeder means that the building served by the primary feeder or substation facility can sustain normal operations until the repair is made, reducing reliance on backup systems.

Action: Repair Existing Electrical Distribution Circuits (District Level)
Description: The condition of a district’s power distribution system may be inadequate if sections of the system have repeated failure or reliability issues. Bringing the distribution system into adequate condition may include replacing aging (especially wooden) poles, replacing aging lines, and undergrounding lines where appropriate that is less than 40 years old, thereby mitigating the risk of fire, wind, wildlife, and physical damage.

Action: Implement Substation Hardening Strategies (District Level)
Description: Substations are susceptible to physical damage (natural or malicious). Hardening a substation at the district level (i.e., adding physical protections) can mitigate the risk of physical damage to the facilities within that district. The degree to which substation hardening is appropriate depends on the substation’s vulnerability to physical damage, which can range from a concrete wall to a Faraday cage.

Action: Install a District-level Microgrid
Description: The U.S. Department of Energy defines a microgrid as “a group of interconnected loads and distributed energy resources within clearly defined electrical boundaries that acts as a single controllable entity with respect to the grid. Having a microgrid can connect and disconnect from the grid to enable it to operate in both grid-connected or island-mode” (Ton and Smith, 2012, p. 84). This strategy considers configuring a district within an installation into a microgrid, enabling greater functionality and more efficient use of resources to continue operations during a utility power outage. Energy generation can also be operationalized to balance loads and contribute to cost savings especially when paired with a microgrid. A microgrid requires appropriate cybersecurity measures.

Action: Mitigate Single Points of Failure / Loop Lines (Power) (District Level)
Description: A single point of failure in the power distribution means that failure at one point causes disruption to all downstream loads. At the district level, a single point of failure can be a single substation transformer or a distribution line. This strategy requires looping all of the distribution lines from the district substation, providing redundant feeders and distribution equipment, and using other strategies that enable alternate routes for power supply whenever an element of the distribution system fails.

Strategy / Capability: Automatic Sectionalizers on Distribution Lines (District Level)
Action: Install Automatic Sectionalizers on Distribution Lines (District Level)
Description: An automatic sectionalizer is a device that automatically opens circuits on the distribution line to isolate faulted sections. Isolating the faulted section limits the extent of an outage caused by failure in the distribution line so more facilities can continue normal operation until the failure is repaired. This strategy is applicable to all local district infrastructure.

Action: Interconnect / Back feed District Substations
Description: Primary substations are subject to failure during unpredictable events. Interconnecting substations can allow a district served by one substation to be sustained by the backup substation if there is a failure at the primary substation. Interconnecting substations means the district served by the substation can sustain normal operations until the repair is made, reducing reliance on backup systems. This strategy is fully in place if it has been tested and confirmed that at least 90% of the installation load is capable of being carried over without the transformer(s) loaded over 75%.

Strategy / Capability: Redundant Electrical Feeder to District Substation (District Level)
Action: Install a Redundant Electrical Feeder to District Substation (District Level)
Description: A primary feeder can be subject to failure during unpredictable events. Providing a redundant electrical feeder to a district substation allows power to be sustained if there is a failure along the primary feeder (supply). A redundant electrical feeder means that the district served by the substation can sustain normal operations until the repair is made, reducing reliance on backup systems.

Action: Upgrade Substation Capacity (District Level)
Description: Existing or projected loads serving a district need to be met to support mission needs. This strategy involves ensuring that the existing substation capacity is adequate to meet all existing or projected loads served by the substation (or increasing currently inadequate substation capacity such that it does).

Strategy / Capability: Remote Substation Monitoring and Controls (District Level)
Action: Upgrade Substation Controls (District Level)
Description: Substation components are subject to failure during unpredictable events. Upgrading substation control packages can provide enhanced protection and remote capabilities for the substation equipment, simplifying the operator’s role. At the district level, substations with better controls can be more easily integrated with the electrical distribution system and can respond promptly in case of failure in the network.

Action: Repair Existing Electrical Transmission Circuits (Installation Level)
Description: The condition of an installation’s power transmission system may be inadequate if sections of the system have repeated failure or reliability issues. Bringing the transmission system into adequate condition may include replacing aging towers, replacing aging lines, or replacing air-insulated substations that are approaching 30 years old with gas-insulated substations.

Action: Replace Existing Overhead Power Lines with Insulated Wires
Description: Lines may spark when hit by foreign objects and create a safety hazard. Replacing overhead power lines with insulated wire reduces the risk of these lines sparking when hit by tree limbs or other objects.

Action: Implement Substation Hardening Strategies (Installation Level)
Description: Substations are susceptible to physical damage (natural or malicious). Hardening a substation at the installation level mitigates the risk of physical damage (natural or malicious) to the installation. The degree to which substation hardening is appropriate depends on the substation’s vulnerability to physical damage, which can range from a concrete wall to a Faraday cage.

Strategy / Capability: Critical Load Connection to Backup Power Circuit (Installation Level)
Action: Connect Critical Loads to Backup Power Circuit (Installation Level)
Description: At the installation level, critical loads can be entire facilities. Dedicating an electrical circuit for critical loads in an installation enables the isolation of critical loads when providing backup power. If not all facilities are critical, the backup power system can be configured to power just the critical facilities, which lowers the sustainment capacity that is required and extends the time frame that loads can be supported during an outage.

Action: Install an Installation-level Microgrid
Description: The U.S. Department of Energy defines a microgrid as “a group of interconnected loads and distributed energy resources within clearly defined electrical boundaries that acts as a single controllable entity with respect to the grid. Having a microgrid can allow connect and disconnect from the grid to enable it to operate in both grid-connected or island-mode” (Ton and Smith, 2012, p. 84). This strategy considers configuring the entire installation as a microgrid, enabling greater functionality and more efficient use of resources to continue operations during a utility power outage. Energy generation can also be operationalized to balance loads and contribute to cost savings especially when paired with a microgrid. A microgrid requires appropriate cybersecurity measures.

Action: Mitigate Single Points of Failure / Loop Lines (Power) (Installation Level)
Description: A single point of failure in the power distribution means that failure at one point causes disruption to all downstream loads. At the installation level, a single point of failure can be a single substation transformer or a transmission line. This strategy requires looping all of the distribution lines from the installation substation, providing redundant feeders and distribution equipment, and using other strategies that enable alternate routes for power supply whenever an element of the transmission/distribution system fails.

Strategy / Capability: Automatic Sectionalizers on Distribution Lines (Installation Level)
Action: Install Automatic Sectionalizers on Distribution Lines (Installation Level)
Description: An automatic sectionalizer is a device that automatically opens circuits on the distribution line to isolate faulted sections. Isolating the faulted section limits the extent of an outage caused by failure of the distribution line so more facilities can continue normal operations until the failure is repaired. This strategy is applicable to all installation infrastructure.

Action: Connect to an Alternative Substation
Description: Utility supply from primary substations is subject to failure during unpredictable events. Connecting the base electrical distribution infrastructure to an alternate off-site utility substation allows at least some of the installation power demand to be met by the alternate substation, reducing the likelihood of a base-wide power outage. Installing or connecting to an alternate substation may also help increase the total capacity available to meet installation power demand.

Action: Interconnect / Back feed Installation Substations
Description: Primary substations are subject to failure during unpredictable events. Interconnecting substations can allow an installation served by one substation to be sustained by the backup substation if there is a failure at the primary substation. Interconnecting substations means that the installation served by the substation can sustain normal operations until the repair is made, reducing reliance on backup systems.

Action: Install Remote Substation Controls / Operations (Installation Level)
Description: The capability to control substation switches remotely may require updating the switchgear at the substation level. Remote control allows the grid operator to quickly reroute power supply to critical loads when a circuit is compromised without the need to send personnel to the location, significantly reducing recovery time.

Action: Secondary Transmission Connection (Utility Provider)
Description: Depending on the nature of the failure, power supply from a secondary utility provider may not be compromised when there is an outage from the primary provider. This strategy considers providing a secondary transmission connection to a different electric utility provider where available. This strategy is superior to a secondary transmission line from the same utility provider.

Strategy / Capability: Redundant Transmission Feeder to Installation Substation(s)
Action: Install a Secondary Transmission Feeder
Description: If a single transmission feeder supplies power to the installation, a failure anywhere along the feeder can disrupt power to the base. This strategy considers providing a secondary transmission connection to the same utility provider. By installing a secondary transmission feeder, either through a redundant feeder to the same substation or an alternate entry point to the installation, backup utility supply can be ensured if there is a failure along the primary transmission supply.

Action: Upgrade Substation Capacity (Installation Level)
Description: Existing or projected loads required by an installation may increase over time. This strategy involves ensuring that the existing substation capacity is adequate to meet all existing or projected loads served by the substation (or increasing currently inadequate substation capacity such that it does).

Strategy / Capability: Remote Substation Monitoring and Controls (Installation Level)
Action: Upgrade Substation Controls (Installation Level)
Description: An installation’s electrical distribution network can be disturbed during a substation failure. Upgrading substation control packages can provide enhanced protection and remote capabilities to substation equipment, simplifying the operator’s role. At the installation level, better substation controls can minimize the impact of substation failures on the installation’s electrical distribution network.

Action: Implement Building Envelope Security/Hardening Strategies
Description: A building envelope is susceptible to damage during unpredictable events. Improving the physical protection of critical facilities can help the facility withstand identified threats to its energy and water supply. This strategy reduces the risk of energy systems being compromised and can include, for example, housing external HVAC components and structural supports for ducting.

Action: Relocate Critical Operations to Secure Facility
Description: The energy and water infrastructure at secure facilities has a reduced risk of disruption due to greater levels of protection and facility hardness than at non-secured facilities. Properly securing critical energy and water infrastructure operations allows the operations to be more resilient by reducing exposure to risk of disruption.

Action: Upgrade/Install Base-Wide SCADA System (Wastewater)
Description: SCADA systems for wastewater allow personnel to monitor and, if necessary, operate all of the installation’s water systems from a single terminal and/or remotely. The implementation of SCADA systems can reduce workforce needs, allow rapid identification of equipment failures, and speed recovery from failures. SCADA systems require appropriate cybersecurity measures. SCADA systems for wastewater are applicable only at installations with dedicated wastewater treatment plants.

Action: Install Low-Flow Plumbing Fixtures
Description: Replacing conventional plumbing fixtures with low-flow fixtures (e.g., toilets, faucets, showers) decreases facility water demand, which reduces the sustained capacity requirement for the installation.

Action: Implement Water Conservation Measures (Building Level)
Description: Water supply sources can be limited and unsustainable over time. Implementing water conservation measures at the facility level can decrease facility water demand, which reduces potential strain on water supply sources and improves critical sustainment capacity.

Strategy / Capability: Alternate Water Supply Connection for Cooling Equipment
Action: Install an Alternative Water Supply Connection for Cooling Equipment
Description: Cooling equipment is often the primary critical water need in a facility. This strategy involves installing an alternate connection (e.g., second piped connection, portable water tank connection, secondary potable water connection) for cooling equipment.

Strategy / Capability: Non-potable Water Supply Connection for Cooling Equipment
Action: Install a Non-potable Water Supply Connection for Cooling Equipment
Description: Cooling equipment does not necessarily require potable water for operation. If non-potable water is available (especially if it is from on-base treatment), replacing potable water with recycled, non-potable water for cooling can improve supply reliability and alleviate potable water supply constraints. Adding a non-potable connection can also serve as a backup in case of failure in the primary water supply.

Action: Backup Water Supply (Building Level)
Description: If the main water utility supply to the facility fails, a backup means of supplying water (e.g., local storage tank, secondary water pipe, water buffalo connection) can avoid a loss of mission function, especially for facilities with critical water demands.

Action: Install Redundant/Looped Water Line (District Level)
Description: Water systems may be subject to a single point of failure. Installing water distribution lines in a looped configuration (i.e., no dead ends) allows water to be rerouted to sustain supply during a failure at any point (e.g., pipe failure). At the district level, this strategy includes looped distribution from the point of connection to the water main and connection to multiple water mains.

Action: Backup Water Supply (District Level)
Description: If water supply fails at the installation or off-site level, a backup water supply at the district level allows critical water loads within the district to be sustained (e.g.,, water storage tanks that are filled via installation supply and large enough to sustain the district for a sufficient period).

Action: Install Backup Power for Circulation Pumps
Description: If the installation relies on circulation pumps for water distribution (i.e., not gravity fed), water supply can be disrupted in a power outage if the pumps do not have backup power supply. Having backup power can sustain circulation of water supply through an outage.

Strategy / Capability: Backup Power for Lift Stations (Storm/Sanitary Sewer)
Action: Install Backup Power for Water Treatment Plant Equipment
Description: If the installation relies on lift stations for storm and/or sanitary sewer conveyance (i.e., not gravity conveyance), storm/sanitary sewers can begin backing up during a power outage if the lift stations do not have a backup power supply. Backup power can sustain lift station operation during an outage.

Strategy / Capability: Backup Power for Wastewater Treatment Plant
Action: Install Backup Power for Water Treatment Plant Equipment
Description: An installation’s wastewater treatment plant may be a critical load in that lost power can cause backups and damage throughout the installation’s sewer system. Backup power can sustain operation during an outage.

Strategy / Capability: Backup Power for Water Treatment Plant
Action: Install Backup Power for Water Treatment Plant Equipment
Description: If an installation relies on a water treatment plant for potable water supply (i.e., no municipal connection), it may be critical to sustain this load during an outage. Backup power can sustain plant operation during an outage, ensuring that it can maintain supply for critical water demands.

Action: Install Backup Power for Water Wells
Description: Power outages may occur and disrupt water well function. If the installation has water wells for potable water supply, backup power for well pumps can sustain water supply during a power outage.

Action: Install Portable Backup Power Quick-Connect for Wells
Description: If an installation has wells for water supply but the wells are determined to be less critical than those requiring permanent generators (e.g., the wells are redundant or the well field serves as backup to municipal supply), the water supply may be unreliable during an outage. This strategy involves installing a portable generator quick-connect to improve water supply reliability.

Action: Establish a Protocol for Prioritized Emergency Water Allocation
Description: If the installation is facing a water shortage, critical water demands will need to be supplied while noncritical demands can be shed. Some water demands will be a top priority (e.g., water for cooling server racks). Establishing a protocol involves prioritizing critical water demands, similar to generator refueling prioritization, to reduce risk of critical equipment failure during a water supply disruption.

Action: Upgrade Installation-Wide SCADA System (Water)
Description: SCADA systems for water allow personnel to monitor and, if necessary, operate all of the installation’s water systems from a single terminal and/or remotely. SCADA systems can reduce workforce needs, allow rapid identification of equipment failures, and speed recovery from failures. SCADA systems require appropriate cybersecurity measures.

Action: Install Submetering on Water Systems (Installation Level)
Description: Monitoring a building’s system performance allows localized response to issues and optimization opportunities. This strategy identifies equipment that is compromised and resources whose consumption could be reduced. This strategy focuses on monitoring water systems at an installation-wide scale.

Action: Implement Water Distribution Hardening Strategies (Installation Level)
Description: The installation’s water distribution infrastructure is subject to physical damage, such as from a natural disaster or malicious attack. This strategy includes burying the water distribution infrastructure, encasing it in concrete, and routing it through secure areas. The system can be considered sufficiently hardened when the risk to physical damage is deemed to be low and must be balanced with the target of ease of repair/recovery.

Action: Conduct a Water Vulnerability/Resiliency Assessment
Description: A water system may have a single point of failure that causes system failure. Conducting a water vulnerability/resiliency assessment can identify the potential weaknesses in a water supply, treatment, and distribution system. The assessment should be performed by a third party and guide future work to improve the resiliency of the system.

Action: Procure/Increase Emergency Water Truck Capacity
Description: During a disruption to utility water supply, water trucks may be relied on to meet critical water demand. In a widespread and/or prolonged disruption, a single water truck may be insufficient to continuously provide backup water supply. This strategy involves procuring an additional supply truck.

Action: Install Redundant/Looped Water Main (Installation Level)
Description: A single point of failure in the water supply means that failure at one point causes disruption to all downstream service. Configuring the water supply to be able to reroute mitigates the impact of single points of failure. Examples at the installation level are interconnected systems (i.e., ability to back feed) and looped configuration (i.e., no dead ends). Looped water mains can also benefit water quality.

Action: Backup Water Supply (Installation Level)
Description: Many installations rely on a single source for potable water. A backup water supply can serve critical water demands in case of a supply disruption. A backup water supply includes a municipal supply backing up a well field, a well field backing up a municipal supply, or a secondary municipal supply.

Action: Collect Base Water Rights Documentation
Description: Many installations hold rights to the use of surface waters or groundwater. Legally documenting these rights ensures that the installation will have access to water in case of future scarcity.

Action: Collaborative Groundwater Resource Planning
Description: Some bases rely on groundwater supplies that come from aquifers that are also used by other organizations. Having base personnel coordinate with these entities and plan water withdrawals can ensure that there is enough aquifer supply for long-term use. In some cases, this planning is mandated at the state level (e.g., California’s Sustainable Groundwater Management Act).

Action: Install a Reverse Osmosis Processing Unit (ROPU)
Description: ROPUs are transportable equipment that generate potable water from an available source of non-potable water through reverse osmosis. ROPUs can provide emergency water in the case of failure or inoperability of the base’s primary water treatment process.

Action: Install Water Wells
Description: If the installation relies on local water sources for its main water supply (e.g. wells, surface water), ensuring that the well fields have sufficient capacity helps supply peak water demand. If the installation has well field access as backup to a municipal supply, ensuring that the well field has sufficient capacity helps supply critical water demand.

Action: Establish Contractor Emergency Availability Protocol (Water)
Description: If some or all of an installation’s water infrastructure is privatized, the contract or other supporting documentation should include provisions for the contractor’s responsibility in emergencies (e.g., specified response times to failures, priority status in disaster response).

Action: Install an Off-site Domestic Water Connection
Description: Original water sources rely on supply chains that may be subject to failure. An off-site domestic water connection can improve the water supply availability for the installation. This strategy includes a connection to a nearby municipal supply, especially when paired with a well field potable water supply.
